awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Freeze-on of Subglacial Sediments in Experiments and Theory
awd_abstract_narration:
The fastest-changing regions of the Antarctic and Greenland Ice Sheets that contribute most to sea-level rise are underlain by soft sediments that facilitate glacier motion. Glacier ice can infiltrate several meters into these sediments, depending on the temperature and water pressure at the base of the glacier. To understand how ice infiltration into subglacial sediments affects glacier slip, the team will conduct laboratory experiments under relevant temperature and pressure conditions and compare the results to state-of-the-art mathematical models. Through an undergraduate research exchange between University of Wisconsin-Madison, Dartmouth College, and the College of Menominee Nation, Native American students will work on laboratory experiments in one summer and mathematical theory in the following summer.

Ice-sediment interactions are a central component of ice-sheet and landform-development models. Limited process understanding poses a key uncertainty for ice-sheet models that are used to forecast sea-level rise. This uncertainty underscores the importance of developing experimentally validated, theoretically robust descriptions of processes at the ice-sediment interface. To achieve this, the team aims to build on long-established theoretical, experimental, and field investigations that have elucidated the central role of premelting and surface-energy effects in controlling the dynamics of frost heave in soils.  Project members will theoretically describe and experimentally test the role of premelting at the basal ice-sediment interface. The experiments are designed to provide quantitative insight into the impact of ice infiltration into sediments on glacier sliding, erosion, and subglacial landform evolution.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Although it has long been recognized that sliding is responsible for most glacier motion,  we still lack predictive models for the controls on this dynamic process. Some of the fastest sliding, which is responsible for most ice discharge to the oceans, takes place over beds of  water-saturated sediments. This collaborative project was designed to test new model treatments for conditions that cause glacial ice to gradually sink downwards into the  pores between sediment grains, where it forms a layer of partially frozen fringe that affects sliding behavior in ways that  can be examined using controlled laboratory experiments. Our new experimentally validated treatments of sliding behavior should eventually lead to more accurate forecasts for how glacier motion is likely to contribute towards sea-level changes, and how rapidly to anticipate changes to mountain glaciers that play a vital role in water resources and ecological systems. Additional broader impacts of our work included introducing Native American  students, who are underrepresented in STEM fields, to cutting-edge glacier research, training an undergraduate  student in mathematical modeling, mentoring a graduate student in laboratory research, and aiding in the career development of two promising postdoctoral scholars. Major academic findings supported by this research award are summarized in 9 peer-reviewed journal articles that have been uploaded to the NSF-PAR Repository; several additional journal articles that build upon the findings of this work are anticipated over the coming years. Project successes include the experimental growth of frozen fringe beneath sliding ice, with successful comparison to model treatments and control experiments conducted in a different apparatus designed to prohibit ice motion. Our sliding experiments led to the discovery   of a previously unknown mobile mushy zone of loosely ice-bound sediments that was able to deform at slower speeds and significantly affect the bed resistance. In addition to the construction of a predictive model that captures the observed dependence of bed resistance on experimental conditions, further model developments included a new  formulation that allows us to describe how the fringe develops in a more numerically efficient manner than in previous work, and also an extended treatment that accounts for sediment particle rearrangements as the forces communicated between adjacent particles change. We communicated these and other findings in talks at several universities and  conferences, culminating at the close of the grant period on August 4, 2024 in a pair of invited talks by University of Wisconsin Madison PI Lucas Zoet and University of Oregon PI Alan Rempel at the Gordon Conference on Rock Deformation, which brought together an international group of researchers who study the related  processes that control the deformation in Earth's Mantle that facilitates Plate Tectonics, the motion on faults that results in earthquakes and other slip processes, and the slip near Earth's surface that produces landslides.
